bibl.title: Letter from William C. White to Laura Armistead Carter, September 15, 1925

div1.p: White sends his condolences and words of admiration for Henry Carter.

div1.head: Letter from William C. White to Laura Armistead Carter, September 15, 1925
div1.opener:
2901 Connecticut Ave.
Washington D. C.
Sept. 15, 1925.
Miss Laura Carter
The Westmoreland.
My dear Miss Carter
div1.p:
I thought of
coming to see you after reading the account
of your father in this morning's Post, but it
occurred to me that you would be overrun
with callers, and that the kindest thing I
could do was to stay away.

But I do want to tell you how much
I admire the grit with which you carried thru
2.
a trying task, and I know you feel thankful
to God who gave you the strength. It does not
seem to me that you need condolence, in the
ordinary sense, tho you must feel the loss of
your father's companionship. But it must
be a great source of satisfaction to you that you
were able to help him finish his lifework
and I know you are glad to have been close
of kin to one who has done so much for the
world. I count it a great privilege to have
known and talked with your father. And
now I think we are all thankful that, for
him, the pain and weakness are past. May
3.
he rest in peace and may light perpetual shine
on him.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours Wm Curtis White.
